goal.ch:
At the end of the semester, students are expected to achieve following goals.
- knowing the way to write and execute Python script,
- learning basic numerical calculation techniques,
- learning visualisation techniques,
- learning introductory astrophysics.

outline.ch:
The internet, the world-wide computer network, has revolutionised
our society, and computer programming is getting more and more
important for our life. The course “Doing Astrophysics using
Python“ is offered for satisfying both (1) students who is
looking for an opportunity of having practical computer
programming training, and (2) students who is willing to learn
introductory astrophysics through hands-on sessions. Because
Python is getting very popular nowadays, I choose Python as the
main programming language for the course. For this course, basic
Python programming and basic visualisation techniques are
reviewed at the beginning of the semester. Then, students will
start to work on the visualisation of astronomical objects and
phenomena, such as visualisation of spectrum of a star,
visualisation of motion of planets, and locations of stars on the
sky. Plots that we commonly see on textbooks are reproduced, and
those plots help students to understand underlying physics.
Self-compiled lecture note is offered by the instructor each
week. Also, a set of sample Python scripts are provided to
students via a repository on GitHub. Students first download
those sample Python scripts, run those scripts, and see what
happens. Students will then modify a part of those sample scripts
to understand more about Python programming. For executing Python
scripts, we use Google Colaboratory. Therefore, only a web
browser is needed to run Python scripts. Each week, Jupyter
Notebook files are provided, and Python scripts can be executed
easily by running cells on the notebook.
Prerequisites for this course include following.
- first-year undergraduate student level English,
- first-year undergraduate student level mathematics,
- first-year undergraduate student level physics,
- a laptop computer,
- experience of using web browswer (e.g. Firefox, Chrome) on a computer,
- experience of keyboard typing on a computer,
We will have following sessions during the semester.
“Executing a Python script“
“Basic Python programming“
“Importing and using Python modules“
“Using Numpy for calculations“
“Visualisation of data using Matplotlib“
“Scientific calculations and analyses using SciPy“
“Making and using relational database using Python“
“Astronomical calculations using Astropy“
“Blackbody radiation“
“Distribution of asteroids, stars, and galaxies“
“Hubble diagram and expansion of the Universe“
“Estimating ages of star clusters“
“Periodicity analysis of astronomical time-series data“
“Source extraction and image alignment of astronomical images“
“Planetary motion and orbital integration“
“Stars/galaxies/asteroids classification“
